quoteLast: ?  Confound it all! Tom, before night I have to be at the other Dreyel’s.  I have no time for arguing.  No, I don’t want your company; it would only drag you deeper into the mire and I believe Ferlin is already thinking of arresting you...."
title: No. 13 Toroni
author: Regis, Julius, 1889-1925

quoteFirst: He said not a word concerning his mission or designs. He left the rectory about
quoteLast: , as I have said, taking both suit cases.”
title: Nick Carter Stories No. 121, January 2, 1915: The call of death; or, Nick Carter's clever assistant
author: Carter, Nicholas (House name); Jenkins, Burke

quoteFirst: On the 1st of May I went to the Hague, and wrote to his Excellency, Peter Van Bleiswick, Grand Pensionary of Holland, that having something of importance to communicate to him, I proposed to do myself the honor to wait on him the next morning at
quoteLast: , if that time should be agreeable to him; but if any other hour was more convenient, I requested his Excellency to mention it. The answer, which was not in writing, was, that half past eight should be the time.
title: The Diplomatic Correspondence of the American Revolution, Vol. 05
author: Sparks, Jared, 1789-1866 [Editor]

quoteLast: , it must be nearly bed-time. The feast has lasted long enough, with food, drink, and music. Then they all get on their feet, and there is a cry of "Bow and arrows.
title: The South Pole; an account of the Norwegian Antarctic expedition in the "Fram," 1910-1912 — Volume 1
author: Amundsen, Roald, 1872-1928; Nansen, Fridtjof, 1861-1930 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Chater, Arthur G. (Arthur Grosvenor), 1866-1951 [Translator]

quoteFirst: That night when Miss Eliza went home, about
quoteLast: , the woman was gone. She had paid for her room and had been driven as far as Thornville, where all trace of her had been lost.
title: The Case of Jennie Brice
author: Rinehart, Mary Roberts, 1876-1958; Bracker, M. Leone, 1885-1937 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We left the Upper Geyser Basin at
quoteLast: yesterday morning, stopped for lunch at Norris's at noon, and, branching off, arrived here at 3.30 P.M. The road was on the banks of or near the Gibbon River for many miles, and was very rough. Twice we forded the river, and once the passengers were obliged to leave the wagon and remove a fallen tree from the way.
title: Another Summer: The Yellowstone Park and Alaska
author: Gillis, Charles J.

quoteFirst: In the good old days, before there were railroads, such trains as this were frequent. From Manteca the road penetrated into contracting valleys, until finally it might, with propriety, be called a cañon road. At
quoteLast: we reached San Carlos, a mean town with no _meson_ or other regular stopping-place. We left the horses under the shady trees with the old farrier.
title: In Indian Mexico (1908)
author: Starr, Frederick, 1858-1933

quoteFirst: I spent my days when not inspecting outposts as follows:--Getting up before daylight, I exercised the Regiment by troops till
quoteLast: ; saw the Native officers at orderly-room at 10; and then tried to disentangle and arrange the Regimental accounts till 5 p.m., when I went to the Horse Lines, and there remained till 7 p.m. This probably had an exhausting effect on my nervous system, and made me anxious to get away from what I feared must under the existing conditions remain an unsatisfactory Corps, inasmuch as it was financially unsound.
title: From Midshipman to Field Marshal
author: Wood, Evelyn, 1838-1919

quoteFirst: They slept longer, in order to make up for the late hour at which they retired. As they sat down to breakfast, at
quoteLast: , Paul said: “I wonder whether the padrone misses you, Phil?”
title: Phil, the Fiddler
author: Alger, Horatio, Jr., 1832-1899
